items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels are continuing to rise at the Torksey river gauge as a result of snowmelt and rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is still possible. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point, and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. However, further rainfall is forecast overnight on 15/03/2023. We expect river levels to remain high beyond 16/03/2023. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our field team staff have closed the pointing doors at Torksey. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:30 tomorrow, 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.      
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.
Please avoid contact with any standing flood water.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Church Wilne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall and snowmelt. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Church Wilne, Draycott, and Wilne Lane between Draycott and Sawley. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow evening, 15/03/23  
We continue to monitor the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.

River levels are continuing to rise at the Mythe Bridge River gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 14/03/23.   
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore.
Predicted peaks:- Mythe 3.5m to 4.0m, Haw Bridge 4.4m to 4.9m, Sandhurst 2.9m to 3.4m, Friday, 17/03/23.    
Further rainfall is forecast over the next week, and river levels may continue to rise. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. 

We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.
Please avoid contact with flood water.

River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. River levels have peaked and will remain steady, with no further rise forecasted. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 15/03/23 or as the situation changes.
Please note although this flood alert is no longer in force we continue to monitor the weather forecast and river levels.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ure due to recent rain and snowmelt. Low lying land is expected to be most affected, including agricultural land and local roads in the areas around Masham, Boroughbridge, Aldborough and Bishop Monkton. Levels have peaked and are expected to fall during Tuesday evening, 14/03/2023. Further rain is expected and we will continue to monitor the forecast.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 on Wednesday morning, 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels will continue to fall throughout the morning now that the rainfall has eased.
No further significant rainfall is forecast for Tuesday 14/03/2023. Another band of rain is expected overnight from Wednesday 15/03/2023 into Thursday this week. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Ross-On-Wye river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. Predicted Peaks:- Ross on Wye 3.5 to 3.8m this evening, Tuesday 14/03/23. Further rainfall is forecast over the next week. We expect river levels to remain high for a few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 08:00 on Wednesday 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

Lake levels are currently high and will continue to fall throughout today but further rain is forecast from tomorrow, Wednesday 15 March 2023. Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. We will continue to monitor water levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River levels will start to fall this morning as rainfall eases. No property flooding is expected.
The forecast is for no significant rainfall for the rest of the day. However, heavy rainfall is forecast for late Wednesday 15 March 2023 into Thursday.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and to keep closely monitoring the situation.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels will continue to fall today as rainfall eases. 
The forecast is for no further rainfall for the rest of the day. However, heavy rainfall is forecast for late Wednesday the 15th of March into Thursday.
We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and to keep closely monitoring the situation.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Cherwell as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is expected, especially in the Thrupp area. 
The forecast this evening is for outbreaks of rain, clearing away overnight. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse due to recent rain and snowmelt. Areas most at risk include riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. Levels are forecast to peak overnight on Tuesday, 14/03/2023 at York (Viking) at a level of 3.4m. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 on Wednesday morning, 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are continuing to rise at the Bewdley river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 14/03/23.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations affected are Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn. B4195 Stourport Road Dog Lane Bewdley and Riverside Path Stourport. 
Predicted peaks:- Bewdley 3.7m to 4.1m on Thursday morning, 16/03/23, Worcester 4.3m to 4.8m on Thursday evening, 16/03/23, Diglis 3.7m to 4.2m on Thursday evening, 16/03/23, Kempsey Yacht Club 6.0m to 6.5m on Friday, 17/03/23, Saxons Lode 4.5m to 5.0m on Friday, 17/03/23.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next week, and river levels may continue to rise. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further rainfall is forecast over the next day. 
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and remain safe and aware of your local surroundings.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: Water levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. The weather is expected to remain unsettled through the week. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

River levels will continue to fall today as rainfall eases. 
The forecast is for no further rainfall for the rest of the day. However, heavy rainfall is forecast for late Wednesday the 15th of March into Thursday.
We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and to keep closely monitoring the situation.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels remain high at the Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Cae Howel gauges following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 9am on Wednesday 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

River levels are continuing to rise at the Bredon river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin today, 14/03/2023.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and Roads adjacent the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning. Predicted peaks:- Bredon 2.1m to 2.5m on Friday 17/03/2023.   
Further rainfall is forecast during this week, and river levels may continue to rise. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high into Wednesday morning, 15/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.

River levels continue to rise at the Welsh Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge & Bridgnorth. River Severn bankfull at White Abbey.
Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green 6.1 to 6.3m this afternoon 14/03/23, Montford 5.8 to 6.1m on Wednesday morning 15/03/23, Welshbridge 3.4 to 3.7m on Wednesday morning 15/03/23, Buildwas 4.7 to 5.0m on Thursday morning, 16/03/23, Bridgnorth 3.8 to 4.2m Thursday morning 16/03/23. Further rainfall is forecast over the next week. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. The Frankwell barriers have been deployed. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 08:00 on 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.
Please note although this flood alert is no longer in force we continue to monitor the weather forecast and river levels.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Further rainfall is forecast over the next week. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: Heavy rain and snow that fell across the River Nene catchment last week caused the River Nene levels to rise. During periods of high tide the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are operating the Whittlesey washlands to help manage the situation. Although river levels are generally receding, further rainfall is forecast for later in the week. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 09:00 on 15/03/23, or before, if the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Eathorpe river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the last 48 hours.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high into Wednesday morning, 15/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Wiske due to rain and snowmelt on the Yorkshire Dales affecting the River Swale and the backflow effects from this river on the River Wiske, particularly in the Kirby Wiske area. River levels have peaked and are falling this afternoon, 14/03/2023. Further rain is expected on Thursday. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 on Wednesday morning, 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ure at Roecliffe Caravan Park
items.message: The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from now, 3.20pm, on Tuesday 14th March, and over the next few hours. Water levels are expected to continue to rise over the next few hours. This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Wednesday 15th March.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse due to recent rain and snowmelt. Areas most at risk include locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in the Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas. Levels are forecast to peak overnight on Tuesday, 14/03/2023 at York (Viking) at a level of 3.4m. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 on Wednesday morning,15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Bredwardine, Belmont, Old Wye Bridge, Mordiford, and Ross on Wye river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. Wilton lane may be flooded up to the junction with Fishermans Reach, Ross. Predicted peaks: Ross on Wye 3.50m to 3.80m this evening, Tuesday 14/03/23. Further rainfall is forecasted. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 9am, 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: River Nene levels have remained high since the heavy rainfall and snow last week, which led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. River levels are expected to fall slowly over the next 24hrs, but further rainfall is forecast later in the week. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 15/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Sutton Gault and Welney river gauges as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Tuesday 14 March and is likely to continue for the next few days. Flooding is affecting Hundred Foot Washes including the causeways at Sutton Gault and Welney.

UPDATE - Flood water has now receded from the causeway at Earith.

This information is correct as of 16:00 on Tuesday 14 March. The Welney causeway currently has 29cm of water on the road and the causeway at Sutton Gault has 42cm of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Earith Causeway. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Further rainfall is forecast over the rest of the week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, which may be flooded. This message will be updated again tomorrow morning, 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Willington Cableway river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  River levels have peaked and will remain steady, with no further rise forecasted.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse due to recent rain and snowmelt. Areas most at risk include properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge. Flooding is affecting properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge. Levels have peaked and are expected to fall throughout Wednesday, 15/03/2023. Further rain is forecast and levels are expected to rise and fall over the rest of the week. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will update this message as required. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday, 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Rainfall overnight has caused the River Dee to rise and it will continue to do so due to further rainfall throughout today and tomorrow. Access to Townfield Lane is currently cut off. The Dee is forecast to peak at 8.5m at around 23:00 today, 14/03/23. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding is expected to continue.  We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Maesbrook.    
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  River levels are peaking, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  Avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 08:00 on 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high on the River Nidd due to recent rain and snowmelt. Flooding will affect locations near the River Nidd, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly land around the lower River Nidd and its tributaries including Sand Beck, Sike Beck, Pool Beck and Great Gutter. River levels have peaked and are expected to continue falling on Tuesday evening, 14/03/2023 and into Wednesday, 15/03/2023. Further rain is expected on Thursday. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 on Wednesday morning, 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message: While this Flood Alert is being removed the River Avon is still very close to the Flood Alert threshold. Its possible that this Alert will be reissued on Thursday the 16th March 2023.

items.description: River Severn at the Showground and The Quarry, Shrewsbury
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Welshbridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect offices at the showground and Gravel Hill Lane. Predicted peak at Welshbridge 3.4 to 3.7m on Wednesday morning 15/03/23.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next week. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 08:00 on 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high on the River Ouse due to recent rain and snowmelt. Areas most at risk include Naburn Lock buildings and Lock cottages. Levels have peaked and are expected to fall throughout Wednesday, 15/03/2023.  Further rain is forecast and levels are expected to rise and fall over the rest of the week. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will update this message as required. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday, 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding is expected to continue.  We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Melverley including Melverley to Melverley Green and Ponthen to Melverley roads. Predicted peaks:- Crew Green 6.1m to 6.3m this afternoon, Tuesday 14/03/23.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  River levels are peaking, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  Avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 08:00 on 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

River levels remain high on the River Ure due to recent rain and snowmelt. Areas most at risk include low lying land and local roads around Lower Dunsforth, including Ings Road, Mary Lane and the Ings. River levels have peaked and are expected to fall during Tuesday evening, 14/03/2023 and Wednesday, 15/03/2023. Further rain is expected on Tuesday. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 on Wednesday morning, 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Welshbridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue.  We expect flooding to affect Gravel Hill Lane, Sydney Avenue, Victoria Avenue, Frankwell car park and St Julians Friars car park are flooded. Predicted peak at Welshbridge 3.4 to 3.7m on Wednesday morning 15/03/23.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next week. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 08:00 on 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is affecting River Great Ouse from Newport Pagnell to Roxton. Further rain is forecast over the rest of the week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is affecting River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly. Further rain is forecast over the rest of the week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Granta in Essex and Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are high at the Linton river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting River Granta from Linton to Babraham. Further rain is forecast over the rest of the week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River Nene levels have remained high since the heavy rainfall and snow last week, which led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. River levels are expected to fall slowly over the next 24hrs, but further rainfall is forecast later in the week. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. We are operating the Whittlesey Washlands to help manage the situation. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 15/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

Further rain is forecast over the rest of the week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rothley Brook and Quorn Brook in Leicestershire
items.message: River levels have risen at the Glenfield river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including the Morrisons parks at Glenfield and Anstey. Low-lying land and farmlands in the Glenfield, Anstey, Thurcaston, Rothley, Newtown Linford, Cropston, Swithland and Quorn areas. River levels have peaked and will remain steady, with no further rise forecasted. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 15/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This Flood alert has been removed. River levels are now falling however further widespread and locally heavy rain is forecast on Wednesday and Thursday which may cause river levels to rise again. Phase 1 flood gates at Yarm will remain closed due to the unsettled forecast and possibility of minor flooding impacts later this week.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further rainfall is forecast until later this week. We will continue to monitor levels. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
